intro: Sida subcuneata, commonly known as the narrow-angled sida, is an annual herbaceous plant native to tropical and subtropical regions. It typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and features slender, branching stems covered in fine hairs. The leaves are alternate, ovate to lanceolate in shape, and often have a hairy surface. Its small, pale yellow flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it produces small, dry fruits called capsules. This plant is often found in disturbed soils and is adapted to thrive in warm, humid climates.
